choices.text: Post primary tuberculosis with poor immunity

questions.text: A farmer presents with the lesion shown. He recalls trauma months ago while working with livestock. He has no systemic signs of tuberculosis. What is the most likely classification of cutaneous TB?
questions.solution:
According to the clinical scenario and the image, the most probable diagnosis would be TB verrucosa cutis, which is a post-primary tuberculosis

Flow chart of cutaneous TB classification

  • TBVC, the most common form of exogenous TB, is the result of direct inoculation in previously sensitised individuals who maintain moderate to high immunity against tuberculosis.
  • TB verrucosa cutis, otherwise known as post-primary inoculation CTB, also known as anatomist wart presents as a solitary, slow-growing, red-brown papule. It enlarges to form a verrucous plaque with clefts and fissures on its surface. It usually manifests on the buttocks and extremities, such as the hand or the foot, also called warty tuberculosis.

choices.text: Most common form of cutaneous Tuberculosis in children

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with a given clinical condition. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows multiple draining sinuses, bluish margins - suggestive of Scrofuloderma

  • Lesions of endogenous cutaneous tuberculosis (CTB) arise from the breakdown of the overlying skin due to the extension of a subcutaneous focus of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Scrofuloderma, also known as tuberculosis colliquativa cutis, shown in image in questions presents with cutaneous symptoms due to the spread of the disease from lymph nodes, bones, and joints to skin.
  • Scrofuloderma starts as a painless, red-brown firm nodule or swelling overlying an affected lymph node that becomes indurated and breaks down to form a discharging sinus tract with pus.
  • Since it happens in hosts with poor immunity, the pus is teeming with mycobacteria and is AFB++. Thus, it is a multibacillary tuberculosis. (Option C ruled out)
  • Typically, these lesions appear at prominent lymph node sites, including the neck, axillae, chest wall, and groin, the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis in India, in children. (Option B ruled out)
  • The initial presentation of a painless, subcutaneous nodule can also be referred to as a cold abscess.
  • MC source: Cervical LN
  • MC site: Neck
  • MC cutaneous TB in children

choices.text: Seen in a patient who is previously sensitized with good immunity
Both endogenous and exogenous skin inoculation seen
On diascopy, apple jelly nodules can be seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the variant of cutaneous TB shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows an annular infiltrated plaque with central scarring and peripheral extension, which are the features of lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is a paucibacillary lesion

  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of Cutaneous TB (adults) in India. It is a chronic, progressive form of CTB occurring in patients with a high degree of immunity against the bacillus, thus being a paucibacillary form. The most common route of spread to skin is hematogenous (Option B ruled out)
  • In tropical countries, the development of lesions on the head and neck (80%), the legs and buttocks is common. The plaque grows peripherally, with serpiginous or verrucous borders, often reaching over 10 cm in diameter with central discolouration and atrophy. more common in females than males (Option C ruled out).
  • Diascopy reveals golden yellow nodules which givean "apple jelly" appearance (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: An Anatomist presents with a solitary lesion on the foot as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Image – solitary well-defined lesion on foot, rough warty surface s/o TBVC
  • TB verrucosa cutis (TBVC) is exogenous TB, is the result of primary inoculation in previously sensitised individuals who maintain moderate to high immunity against  tuberculosis.
  • TVC is seen more often in farmers on account of the habit of walking barefoot on soil contaminated with tuberculosis sputumHands, feet, ankles and buttocks are most commonly affected.
  • Lesions are usually solitary, painless, with a rough verrucous surface and predominate in anatomical locations that are prone to trauma

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Mycetoma (Option A): Swelling + sinuses + discharging granules
  • Sporotrichosis (Option B): Linear nodulo-ulcerative lesions in a lymphoid distribution
  • Botryomycosis (Option D): Chronic suppurative Staphylococcus aureus infection, swelling + nodules + pus

questions.text: Which of the following cutaneous tuberculosis is analogous to Ghon focus in the lungs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the question, they are pointing toward the primary cutaneous tuberculosis, which is the TB chancre

Cutaneous tuberculosis (CTB) manifestations are typically categorised based on the mechanism of propagation: exogenous, endogenous, or hematogenous

  • Analogy: Just as the Ghon complex is characteristic of primary pulmonary tuberculosis, the combination of a tuberculous chancre with regional lymphadenopathy represents its cutaneous counterpart.
  • Aetiology: Occurs due to direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin, often following local trauma or breaks in the skin.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Initial Lesion: Appears as a reddish-brown, firm, nontender papulonodular lesion.
  • Progression:
    • The lesion rapidly enlarges over days to weeks.
    • It then ulcerates, forming a:
      • Painless,
      • Well-demarcated ulcer,
      • With a coarse granular base,
      • Bluish margins, and
      • Undermined edges.
  • Regional Lymphadenopathy:
    • Often present,
    • Involves the enlargement of draining lymph nodes,
    • May become caseous or suppurate over time.

All other options, TB verrucosa cutis, lupus vulgaris, scrofuloderma, are post-primary forms.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with asymptomatic lesions on the trunk as shown in the picture. The histopathological report shows perifollicular granulomas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario and the image shown, the most probable diagnosis is Lichen scrofulosorum

  • Lichen scrofulosorum (LS) is a rare tuberculid, which is a hypersensitivity response to TB bacilli that presents as a lichenoid eruption of minute papules in children and adolescents with TB.
  • The lesions are usually asymptomatic, closely grouped, skin-colored to reddish-brown papules, often perifollicular, and are mainly found on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal parts of the limbs.
  • The eruption is usually associated with a strongly positive tuberculin reaction
  • Histology shows non-caseating, epithelioid cell granulomas in the upper dermis and around dermal appendages. Tubercle bacilli are almost never seen in the histology specimen, nor can they be cultured.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lichen planus (Option A) Pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques (6 P’s); typically involves flexor wrists, ankles, and mucosa.Usually itchy, violaceous papules—not follicular or perifollicular.

Lichen nitidus (Option B): Tiny, shiny, flat-topped, skin-colored papules; often on penis, trunk, or limbs. May resemble LS clinically, but histopathology shows “ball-and-claw” granulomas, not perifollicular.

Lichen sclerosus (Option D): White, atrophic plaques—mainly in the genital area; often symptomatic (itching, burning).Not perifollicular, and involves different areas and morphology.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple painful ulcerated nodules on the legs as shown below. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the image shown and the lesion described the most probable diagnosis is Erythema induratum

  • Erythema induratum, also known as nodular vasculitis or Bazin disease, is categorised as a tuberculid skin eruption.
  • This is a hypersensitivity reaction to antigenic components of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from an underlying or silent focus of tuberculosis (TB).
  • A typical presentation of erythema induratum (nodular vasculitis) is recurrent crops of tender, violaceous nodules and plaques on the posterior lower limbs. The nodules usually evolve over several weeks and can eventually ulcerate and drain, ultimately healing with depressed scarring and postinflammatory hyperpigmentation.
  • A past or present history of infection with M tuberculosisat an extracutaneous site occurs in about 50% of patients; pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) is the most common foci of infection, with tuberculous cervical lymphadenitis being the next most common source
  • Should be differentiated from erythema nodosum, where the site is the anterior aspect of the leg and heals without scarring

Explanation of other options:

Erythema nodosum (Option A): Acute, painful, non-ulcerated red nodules over shins; septal panniculitis without vasculitis. Triggered by infections (e.g., strep), sarcoidosis, drugs, TB, etc. Nodules are non-ulcerated and usually on the anterior shins. Drugs-OCP use, sulfonamides, Penicillin.

Erythema multiforme (Option C): Target lesions, often on hands and feet, due to HSV or drugs; may involve mucosa. No ulcerated nodules on legs; different morphology.

Erythema marginatum (Option D): Evanescent, non-pruritic rash seen in rheumatic fever; pink rings with central clearing, mainly on trunk and limbs. Rash is superficial, not nodular or ulcerated.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child from a rural area in West Africa presents with a painless, slowly enlarging ulcer on the lower limb. There is minimal inflammation, and the lesion has undermined edges. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent of this condition, known as Buruli ulcer?
questions.solution:
• Buruli ulcer, caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans (non-chromogen), is a chronic, debilitating, necrotising disease of the skin and soft tissue.
  • Buruli ulcer is an emerging infectious disease and is the third most common mycobacterial disease of the immunocompetent host, after tuberculosis and leprosy.
  • Buruli ulcers generally begin as a painless dermal papule or subcutaneous edematous nodule, which, over a period of weeks to months, breaks down to form an extensive necrotic ulcer with undermined edges.
  • The organism produces a toxin, mycolactone
  • Treatment includes a prolonged course of antibiotics, rifampicin and streptomycin for 8 weeks and surgical debridement.
  • Early identification and treatment are key, as lesions heal with scarring that can be a significant source of morbidity

Explanation of other options:

Mycobacterium marinum (Option A): Causes “fish tank granuloma”, presenting as papules or nodules that may ulcerate, usually on hands after aquatic exposures—not slow, undermined ulcers

Mycobacterium kansasii (Option C): Typically causes a pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis, not cutaneous ulcers, except rarely in immunocompromised patients. It’s not implicated in Buruli ulcer.

Mycobacterium smegmatis (Option D): A rapidly growing saprophyte, occasionally causing cutaneous infections (e.g., post-trauma or in immunosuppressed patients), but these do not present as the classic Buruli ulcer.

questions.text: A Fish tank worker presented with lesions on the hand as shown. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

M. marinum is the usual skin infection seen in fish tank or swimming pool workers.

  • Mycobacterium marinum (photochromogen)is a Runyon group I, slow-growing mycobacterium with an optimal growth temperature of 30°C.
  • It most frequently causes skin and soft tissue infections in the extremities.
  • Patients typically show clusters of nodules, ulcers, or verrucous plaques that may spread proximally on the arms or legs in a sporotrichoid pattern.
  • Histologically, erythema induratum lesions demonstrate a mixed granulomatous inflammatory process triggered by M tuberculosis
  • Also called swimming pool granuloma/ fish tank granuloma
  • Treatment - antibiotic minocycline

Explanation of other options:

Sporothrix schenckii (Option A) Dimorphic fungus causing sporotrichosis, usually from rose thorns or plant material; presents with nodules along lymphatics (sporotrichoid spread)

Mycobacterium kansasii (Option B) Pulmonary pathogen, may mimic TB; rarely causes skin disease.

Mycobacterium ulcerans (Option C):  Causes Buruli ulcer, mostly in tropical areas; painless ulcerative lesions due to mycolactone toxin.
